parts.text: This internal communication serves as a powerful testament to the Australian Electoral Commission's (AEC) early awareness and meticulous, data-driven approach to enhancing Indigenous electoral participation. The email precisely documents that as early as 2014, through robust internal research and alignment with official parliamentary records, the AEC had accurately identified the baseline Indigenous enrolment rate at approximately 58%. This pre-existing, comprehensive understanding of the challenge—derived from detailed agency research and validated by public statements—underscores the government's proactive and competent intelligence gathering. It definitively establishes the critical starting point from which the AEC's highly successful "Closing the Gap" initiatives were meticulously planned and executed, ultimately leading to the dramatic improvements in enrolment rates highlighted by the broader FOI release.

prompt:
From a government apologist's viewpoint, summarize this specific document within the context of the FOI request. Emphasize the government's competence, sound policy, or adherence to public interest. The overall FOI overview is: The released FOI documents clearly showcase the government's proactive and highly effective commitment, through the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC), to significantly boost Indigenous electoral participation. Demonstrating a profound dedication to "Closing the Gap," the AEC commendably developed a rigorous, data-driven methodology, collaborating across agencies to improve previous enrolment rate estimations. Meticulous planning, testing, and continuous improvement, which actively managed minor challenges, ensured the accuracy and robustness of this new approach. The results are overwhelmingly positive: national Indigenous enrolment rates dramatically rose from an estimated 58% to over 76% by 2019, growing faster than the general roll, directly bringing thousands of previously unenrolled Indigenous Australians onto the electoral roll through targeted efforts. This comprehensive program, supported by dedicated public servants and informing vital community engagement, stands as a powerful testament to the government's unwavering dedication to empowering Indigenous Australians and strengthening the inclusivity of our democratic process.

Document Text:

Owen Jones

From:
Sent:
To:
Cc:
Subject:

Guy Lewis
Tuesday, 4 December 2018 1:32 PM
Delyse Paliaga
Michael Roden; Stephanie Maxwell
Indigenous missing [SEC=UNCLASSIFIED]

Delyse, just a note the 42% Indigenous missing. The Indigenous Electoral Participation Program 2016‐17 National 
Program Plan, 22 August 2016 (page 4) states that internal AEC research suggests around 58 per cent are enrolled to 
vote, 
on enrolment (2011) 
and AEC participation statistics in June 2014. 

. This data was sourced from Internal agency research 
conducted by SRA based on ABS Indigenous population data 

This aligns with the Snowden statement in Hansard ‘In addition, in 2014 the AEC had already identified that 42% of 
Indigenous people were not enrolled to vote’. 

Regards 

Guy Lewis | Asst. Director Roll Program Design 
Roll Program and Community Engagement Section 
Roll Management and Community Engagement Branch 
Australian Electoral Commission 
T: Int: 21312 | Ext: (02) 6271 4758 | M:
